Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Launch the default shell with superuser privileges
Answers.Most Similar NL2Bash Task: Search "input.txt" for regex patterns only matching those listed in "ignore.txt", list the unique lines and prefix with the number of occurrences

grep.-f:
Obtain patterns from FILE, one per line. If this option is used multiple times or
 is combined with the -e (--regexp) option, search for all patterns given. The
 empty file contains zero patterns, and therefore matches nothing.
grep.-o:
Print only the matched (non-empty) parts of a matching line, with each such part on
 a separate output line.

uniq.-c: prefix lines by the number of occurrences

grep.man1_grep_9973:
match pattern input text
support simpl pattern regular express invert match exclud specif string print 3 line c ontext around b efor fter match print file name correspond line number match search pattern r ecurs current directori show match line n umber gnore non-text file search pattern within file search exact string use extend regular express support
+ case-insensit mode use standard input instead file

sort.man1_sort_31880: sort line text file sort file ascend order sort file case-insensit way sort file descend order sort file preserv uniqu line sort file use numer rather alphabet order sort human-read number case 5th field ls -lh sort number expon sort passwd file 3rd field numer

uniq.man1_uniq_35301:
output uniqu line given input file
sinc detect repeat line unless adjac need sort first display line display number occurr line along line display number occurr line sort frequent display duplic line display uniqu line

This option is a synonym for -Ireplace-str if replace-str is specified. If the
 replace-str argument is missing, the effect is the same as -I{}. This option is
 deprecated; use -I instead.

Explanations about Options.-r:
Display the kernel routing tables. See the description in route(8) for details. netstat
 -r and route -e produce the same output.
Explanations about Options.-n: Show numerical addresses instead of trying to determine symbolic host, port or user names.

Top-3 Similar Questions: nl2bash_11884: Archive "source" to "root@remote_server_name:/opt/backups" via ssh on port 3382 and compress data during transmission
Top-3 Scripts: nl2bash_11884: rsync -avz --rsh='ssh -p3382' source root@remote_server_name:/opt/backups

Explanations about Options.-v:
This option increases the amount of information you are given during the transfer.
 By default, rsync works silently. A single -v will give you information about what
 files are being transferred and a brief summary at the end. Two -v options will
 give you information on what files are being skipped and slightly more information
 at the end. More than two -v options should only be used if you are debugging
 rsync.
Explanations about Options.--rsh:
This option allows you to choose an alternative remote shell program to use for
 communication between the local and remote copies of rsync. Typically, rsync is
 configured to use ssh by default, but you may prefer to use rsh on a local network.
Explanations about Options.-z:
With this option, rsync compresses the file data as it is sent to the destination
 machine, which reduces the amount of data being transmitted - something that is
 useful over a slow connection.
Explanations about Options.-a:
This is equivalent to -rlptgoD. It is a quick way of saying you want recursion and
 want to preserve almost everything (with -H being a notable omission). The only
 exception to the above equivalence is when --files-from is specified, in which case
 -r is not implied.

nl2bash_9318: diff -dbU0 a b | tail -n +4 | grep ^- | cut -c2-

Explanations about Options.-h:
Suppress the prefixing of file names on output. This is the default when there is
 only one file (or only standard input) to search.
Explanations about Options.-f:
Obtain patterns from FILE, one per line. If this option is used multiple times or
 is combined with the -e (--regexp) option, search for all patterns given. The
 empty file contains zero patterns, and therefore matches nothing.
Explanations about Options.-o:
Print only the matched (non-empty) parts of a matching line, with each such part on
 a separate output line.

Answers.MP Summary: stream editor for filtering and transforming text
Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Replace separator / by any other character not used in the find or replace patterns, e.g., #
Answers.Most Similar NL2Bash Task: Search "input.txt" for regex patterns only matching those listed in "ignore.txt", list the unique lines and prefix with the number of occurrences

grep.-f:
Obtain patterns from FILE, one per line. If this option is used multiple times or
 is combined with the -e (--regexp) option, search for all patterns given. The
 empty file contains zero patterns, and therefore matches nothing.
grep.-o:
Print only the matched (non-empty) parts of a matching line, with each such part on
 a separate output line.

uniq.-c: prefix lines by the number of occurrences

match pattern input text
support simpl pattern regular express invert match exclud specif string print 3 line c ontext around b efor fter match print file name correspond line number match search pattern r ecurs current directori show match line n umber gnore non-text file search pattern within file search exact string use extend regular express support
+ case-insensit mode use standard input instead file

Explanations about Options.-iname:
Like -name, but the match is case insensitive. For example, the patterns `fo*' and
 `F??' match the file names `Foo', `FOO', `foo', `fOo', etc. The pattern `*foo*`
 will also match a file called '.foobar'.
Explanations about Options.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.
Explanations about Options.-d: A synonym for -depth, for compatibility with FreeBSD, NetBSD, MacOS X and OpenBSD.

Top-3 Similar Questions: nl2bash_9363: Print all filenames in /usr/src except for those that are of the form '*,v' or '.*,v'
Top-3 Scripts: nl2bash_9363: find /usr/src -not \( -name "*,v" -o -name ".*,v" \) '{}' \; -print

Answers.Most Similar NL2Bash Task: Search "input.txt" for regex patterns only matching those listed in "ignore.txt", list the unique lines and prefix with the number of occurrences

grep.-f:
Obtain patterns from FILE, one per line. If this option is used multiple times or
 is combined with the -e (--regexp) option, search for all patterns given. The
 empty file contains zero patterns, and therefore matches nothing.
grep.-o:
Print only the matched (non-empty) parts of a matching line, with each such part on
 a separate output line.

uniq.-c: prefix lines by the number of occurrences

Top-3 Similar Questions: nl2bash_7315: find all the files ending with ".sh" in the folder /dir excluding those wth the names foo and bar.
Top-3 Scripts: nl2bash_7315: find /dir \( -name foo -prune \) -o \( -name bar -prune \) -o -name "*.sh" -print

Explanations about Options.-n: like -l, but list numeric user and group IDs
Explanations about Options.-o: like -l , but do not list group information
Explanations about Options.-a: do not ignore entries starting with .
Explanations about Options.-u:
with -lt: sort by , and show , access time; with -l: show access time and sort by
 name; otherwise: sort by access time, newest first
Explanations about Options.-m: fill width with a comma separated list of entries

Answers.MP Summary: show information about a data transfer
